bio:treatment.description: Plants (2–)3–6(–9) cm. Stems dark red to reddish brown when old; micronemata present. Leaves yellow-green or dark green, somewhat contorted when dry, broadly obovate, elliptic, or occasionally orbicular, 3–6(–7) mm; margins green or reddish, 1-stratose; apex rounded or occasionally obtuse, truncate, or retuse, rarely short-apiculate; costa 7/8 leaf length to subpercurrent or rarely percurrent, sometimes 2-fid distally; medial laminal cells elongate, (45–)60–90(–100) µm, weakly collenchymatous, walls weakly pitted; marginal cells linear, ± rectangular, or rhomboidal, in 1–2(–3) rows. Sexual condition synoicous. Seta (1.3–)2–5 cm. Capsule ovate or subglobose, 1.5–2.5 mm; operculum conic-rostrate; exostome dark brown, lamellae less than 20. Spores (28–)40–50 µm.
Wetlands, calcareous and rich in nutrients, swamps, fens, seeps on moist soil, peat, humus;
Greenland; Alta., B.C., Man., N.B., Nfld. and Labr., N.W.T., Ont., Que., Sask., Yukon; Alaska, Calif., Colo., Maine, Mich., Mont., N.Y., Oreg., Wyo.; Europe; Asia.
bio:treatment.discussion: Rhizomnium pseudopunctatum is the sole synoicous species of the genus in the flora area. See discussion for this species under 5. Rhizomnium magnifolium.
